fr:title.text: Homotopy category of a homotopical category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Homotopy category of a homotopical category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The homotopy category \operatorname {Ho} M of a homotopical category M with weak equivalences W is the localization of M at W. By the universal property of localization, this extends to a functor \operatorname {Ho} from homotopical categories to categories.
A class of morphisms S is saturated if it creates isomorphisms under localization C\xrightarrow {Q} C[S^{-1}].

fr:title.text: Construction of the localization of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of the localization of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The localization C_S of a category C at S is exhibited by the following (not necessarily small) construction:

fr:ul.fr:li: the objects of C_S are those of C;

a morphism in C_S is a zig-zag of morphisms in C, where the "rightward" maps consist only of those in S, modulo the relations generated by composition, the identities, and the equations x\xrightarrow {s}y\xleftarrow {s}x \sim 1_x and y\xleftarrow {s}x\xrightarrow {s} y \sim 1_y whenever s\in S.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The embedding Q sends x\xrightarrow {f} y to the "singleton" zig-zag x\xrightarrow {f} y, and inverts S by construction. To exhibit the universal property, suppose C\xrightarrow {F} D is given and inverts S. Then define F_S on a zig-zag by mapping it over the zig-zag and composing in D. The diagram commutes on the nose (note in particular that the relations on C_S don't break this, because they hold in D as well; this is essentially the universal property of the quotient), so it remains to show the uniqueness property. But the functor must act appropriately on the inclusion and preserve composites, so this is immediate.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
A morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in a category is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{-1}}x such that f^{-1}f = 1_x and ff^{-1} = 1_y, i.e.
commute. If there exists an isomorphism between x and y, we say they are isomorphic and write x\cong y.
